discussion.content:
802.1X uses three terms that you need to know. The user or client that wants to be authenticated is called a supplicant. The actual server doing the authentication, typically a RADIUS server, is called the authentication server. And the device in between, such as a wireless access point, is called the authenticator.
802.1X is a standard for port-based network access control (PNAC), but it does not inherently provide any single sign-on functionality.
You see supplicant choose 802.1X
Mainly a server that is a supplicant connected to authenticator, which is switch or access point. And 802.1x is used to authenticate users between RADIUS server and an access point or a switch.
It is clearly stated here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_802.1X
Interesting...The first word that jumped out to me was "supplicant" The IEEE 802.1X standard uses the term "supplicant" to refer either to hardware or to software. <wikipedia>

questions.question_text: A wireless network uses a RADIUS server that is connected to an authenticator, which in turn connects to a supplicant. Which of the following represents the authentication architecture in use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Compensating: A security measure that takes on risk mitigation when a primary control fails or cannot completely meet expectations. (From Comptia Security+ Guide)

d-
A compensating control, also called an alternative control, is a mechanism that is put in place to satisfy the requirement for a security measure that is deemed too difficult or impractical to implement at the present time.
compensating controlsâ€”Security controls that are alternative controls used when a primary security control is not feasible.

Even if you can't update the encryption method aren't there other preventive controls that you can use? The questions is asking what 'control is best at reducing risk' not 'reducing the IMPACT of the risk' which is why I'd argue that the answer might not be compensating. Hopefully someone comes through and can shed some more light on this

comments.content: You cant do a lot of "prevention" when it comes specifically to their end not being able to handle competent encryption. So we must compensate. I understand where you are coming from. Think of it like this...The CEO says "those bastards and their legacy machines are causing us to downgrade our encryption!! what are we doing about that?" We really cant prevent anything in the given context, but we can "make up" for it with other controls! We find a way to compensate!

discussion.content: way not B?

comments.content: "Company is unable to upgrade to the encryption standard", because you're unable to mitigate the risk, you have to do something that will "make up" for the missed chance to increase security. Which means compensating to me

questions.question_text: A recent audit uncovered a key finding regarding the use of a specific encryption standard in a web application that is used to communicate with business customers. Due to the technical limitations of its customers, the company is unable to upgrade the encryption standard. Which of the following types of controls should be used to reduce the risk created by this scenario?

discussion.content:
"No OS patches were applied"!!
Why C?!

comments.content:
We can eliminate B and D as the hash has not changed.
A is saying the hash changed simply due to executing the file - This statement isn't mentioning anything regarding the file being changed. Assuming nothing changed then executing cmd.exe should result in no hash change.
Hashing algorithms rely on the content of the file to determine the hash of the file. Unless the file has changed its own content upon execution, or you have written to the file in some way (even metadata within the file itself), then the hash will not change. One flipped bit in a file will cause an entirely new hash in a secure hashing algorithm. 

I could see A to be only correct if it said that "The cmd.exe was executed on the scanned server between the two dates AND the file has changed its own content upon execution. An incident ticket should be created"

choices.C: The cmd.exe was updated on the scanned server. An incident ticket should be created.
choices.D: The iexplore.exe was updated on the scanned server. An incident ticket should be created.
choices.A: The cmd.exe was executed on the scanned server between the two dates. An incident ticket should be created.
choices.B: The iexplore.exe was executed on the scanned server between the two dates. An incident ticket should be created.

discussion.content:
Should be DF.
DNS by default is running in UDP port 53
I agree: DF is a better answer. TCP/53 is usually used for DNS zone transfer, not for DNS request.
D and E because, DNSSEC uses TCP 53 port for communication and "Secure webs services" run on port 443 HTTPS.
D and E because, DNSSEC uses TCP 53 port for communication and "Secure webs services" run on port 443 HTTPS.
Where is specified that the implementation required DNSSec?

Port 53 TCP is for zone transfers.
Port 53 UDP is for queries and resolution.
My choice is D and F
Really going to make me remember if it is UDP or TCP eh....
UDP is for name so F should be the answer!
Looks like they changed the answer to D and F.

comments.content:
My screen still shows D and E!! They change it back? Read here "Furthermore, most organizations have also used firewalls to block TCP port 53 to and from their DNS servers and the Internet. This is double-protection in case the DNS server accidentally allowed transfers.

Configuring your DNS servers to permit zone transfers to only legitimate DNS servers has always been and continues to be a best practice. However, the practice of denying TCP port 53 to and from DNS servers is starting to cause some problems. There are two good reasons that we would want to allow both TCP and UDP port 53 connections to our DNS servers. One is DNSSEC and the second is IPv6." 
FROM https://www.networkworld.com/article/2231682/cisco-subnet-allow-both-tcp-and-udp-port-53-to-your-dns-servers.html
Maybe this is a new 601 question....things are changing....it could also be that it mentions internal DNS, not facing the net, so in that case they could allow for tcp, so long as they have all access from the internet blocked off....another stupid question without all the info to make a decision

discussion.content:
Yeah seems like another incorrect answer. It should be DF. 
DNSSEC uses TCP 53 as packets can be larger than 512 bytes; which is the limit for UDP.

questions.question_text: A security technician is configuring a new firewall appliance for a production environment. The firewall must support secure web services for client workstations on the 10.10.10.0/24 network. The same client workstations are configured to contact a server at 192.168.1.15/24 for domain name resolution. Which of the following rules should the technician add to the firewall to allow this connectivity for the client workstations? (Choose two.)
A small enterprise decides to implement a warm site to be available for business continuity in case of a disaster. Which of the following BEST meets its requirements?

choices.B: A site used for its data backup storage that houses a full-time network administrator
choices.D: A site staffed with personnel requiring both equipment and data to be relocated there in case of disaster.
choices.A: A fully operational site that has all the equipment in place and full data backup tapes on site
choices.C: An operational site requiring some equipment to be relocated as well as data transfer to the site

discussion.content: Itâ€™s c for me
Should be A

comments.content: It is small company cant afford to pay for hot site, so it needs to be warm
That would be a Hot Site not Warm.
the scenario is for "A small enterprise". It may not be feasible for such enterprises to keep full time staff at its recovery site.

discussion.content: C and D are the same statements with different wording

https://mk0cybersecuritxhwmn.kinstacdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Warm-site.png
A warm site is a type of facility an organization uses to recover its technology infrastructure when its primary data center goes down. A warm site features an equipped data center but no customer data. The warm site has some or all of the IT equipment found in a typical primary data center, such as software and hardware.

comments.content:
Source: https://searchdisasterrecovery.techtarget.com/definition/warm-site
A warm site is a type of facility an organization uses to recover its technology infrastructure when its primary data center goes down. A warm site features an equipped data center but no customer data.

The warm site has some or all of the IT equipment found in a typical primary data center, such as software and hardware. After a disaster at the primary site, an organization will introduce customer data and may install additional equipment at the warm site.

discussion.content: Its should be A?
